title: The Ironsung Measure
description: Two days from Veylcrest, where the city’s blue lamps taper to lantern-streaks along the mule track, the Ironsung Pass exhales a choir of stone that has kept miners safe for generations. Wind funnels through fluted caverns and the walls hum like tuned glass, and pick-crews work to measures cut by an empire that timed its marches to survive avalanches. Now a newborn shaft has found a note no throat can hold, a serrated pitch that skims marrow and scrapes language from the tongue until even curses fall as whispers. The Ledger’s papers say the rhythm is harmless so long as quotas are met, but the mountain is deaf to charters and the mountain has found a way to speak. Sera Flintline’s dust-veil smells of honest stone and stubborn wages when she calls you, and Bell-Marshal Arla Third-Tone steps from the shadows with a hand on the railing, counting silences on her fingers like rosary beads. You descend by lamp and bell, past archways where old measures are etched and past a collapsed gallery where echo-kelp hangs like glass moss, and the note finds you like a thin blade slipped between ribs. It cuts through thought in clean strokes until you find the drum tower the empire left behind, copper plates etched with scores that remember orders the wind still knows. If the Diadem’s hidden hum and this discordant shaft are the same melody played in cruel keys, then the city itself is an instrument and some unseen hand is strumming it. Your task is not to smash the silence nor to let it swallow song, but to wedge the mountain’s throat to a safer register, to read the copper music, to retune labor’s breath so work may proceed without breaking souls. Do that, and the Pass will go back to breathing like a bellows instead of a blade; fail, and the law of resonance will write its verdict in rockfall and broken voices.
objectives: Travel to Ironsung Pass and meet Sera Flintline at the headworks.
Consult with Arla Third-Tone on safe descent timing based on resonance.
Enter the new shaft and locate the source of the dissonant note.
Discover and decipher an imperial drum tower with scores etched in copper.
Re-tune the shaft using a resonant stone wedge to stop harmful amplification.
Return a sample of resonant stone to Dorn Rigger for analysis.

dialogue.speaker: Sera Flintline
dialogue.lines: Our picks sing when we ask and fall quiet when we tell them, and that is the bargain that keeps families eating and stone behaving. This new shaft has no courtesy; it throws a needle of sound that slips past earplugs and prayer and makes the strongest foreman grip the wall like the ground has turned to water. I have three women who now speak only in breath-scratches, and two men who will not enter a tunnel if the lamps are blue instead of yellow because they say blue carries the note farther. I did not lay my lease and my guild’s name on a vein that shreds voices, and I will not let a law of air unmake a law of work. Bring me a silence that respects labor and the rhythm that keeps us safe, not the kind that smothers breath and makes widows of wages.

dialogue.speaker: Arla Third-Tone
dialogue.lines: Resonance is a law like any other, but this shaft cheats by amplitude the way a liar cheats by speaking too loud for truth to be heard. I can time the troughs; the wave rises on a count of seven and falls on a count that feels like five-and-a-half, which means something in that drum tower is gapped and ghosting beats. We will walk on the soft steps between the hard ones, and your bell must not ring true, only near, because a true ring may wake the mountain’s memory of marching feet. If the empire’s measure still sleeps in copper, we must read it as a hymn and as a warning, for war-songs drive men forward but they also bring cliffs down when sung backward. Follow my hand, breathe when I close my eyes, and if I tell you to freeze, you freeze even if the earth tells you to dance.

dialogue.speaker: Thalen Vire
dialogue.lines: The Diadem’s secret gallery hums like a glass throat on a cold night, and this shaft screams like an iron lung that has forgotten how to exhale; if both are tuned to a hidden tonic, then our city is being played without consent. I have no wish to blast or to brag at the mountain, only to set a resonant stone where the wave bites its own tail and bleeds its edge into kindness. My silt-bell will speak in the aqueduct’s register to calm the eddies in the air, and my lens will show me where the rock is bright with strain and where it is dark with rest. We will read the copper scores as contracts with breath, not as orders to conquer, and I will wedge the throat here so the note rounds into something a body can carry without cracking. If we do this properly, the miners will go back to keeping time with songs that fill lungs, and the mountain will go back to breathing with them instead of against them.

dialogue.speaker: Dorn Rigger
dialogue.lines: I cannot spare a day to climb your flute-caves, Thalen, but I can spare you a pocketful of better sense and a sketch of a wedge that will not split a seam into grief. Stone remembers, more faithfully than men and certainly more faithfully than charters, and a wedge is a promise that must be placed with respect for grain and echo. Do not match the note; that is pride and pride is a chisel held backward, but lean near it and let the wedge harvest what the wave wastes. If you find an imperial drum tower, read the rests as commandments, not the strikes, for it is the spaces between blows that keep halls standing. Bring me a chip of whatever sings in there, and I will test it against the Diadem’s hum; if the melodies rhyme, I will know which wall of the city is listening when it should be stone.

choices.title: Walk the troughs by Arla’s count
choices.text: You decide to trust Arla’s fingertip metronome and move only when her eyes close and open in that unsettling half-beat she described. Every step is a negotiation with a wave you cannot see, only feel grazing the edge of your teeth and the scar on your throat. You speak through the Conch of Slack Water to keep your tongue from joining the stone’s argument, and you let the shaft’s breath pass over you like surf that never breaks. When the drum tower appears, its copper plates do not glare but listen, and you listen back, tracing the rests with a gloved finger until the pattern becomes a safe staircase. The wedge goes in not with a hammer’s shout but with a craftsman’s sigh, and the mountain accepts the change with the dignity of a great beast settling its weight in sleep.
choices.outcome: The cruel note rounds off into a working hum that miners can match without losing their names, and Sera’s crews test the new measure with a cautious chorus that does not falter. Arla marks the shaft with a bell-code in chalk that reads, ‘Safe in halves, safer in patience,’ and the foremen adopt the count as if it were law. Sera honors her word with iron scrip and a promise of stone that will one day carry your name in a guild vote, and her hard eyes soften when the whispering victims try their first full sentences in days. Dorn later confirms that the resonant chip you bring him rhymes with a low tone in the Diadem’s broken gallery, and his mouth thins as he notes the key. You earn access to the storage roads as crews wave you through with respect, and the Azurite ledger marks your standing up a notch, even if the Ledger’s masks take note that work resumed without their blessing.

choices.title: Drown the razor-note with measured hush
choices.text: You take out the Third-Tone silt-bell and do what you swore you would do only in canal tunnels and flood courts: you ring for hush in a place that breathes for a living. The bell does not sing so much as remember silence, and the shaft folds around the memory like cloth drawing around a needle, smoothing the edge until the sound grows heavy and docile. You move quickly during the thick quiet, reading copper by lamp-shadow and placing the wedge where the hush pools deepest, then you ease the bell’s memory back into its ampule of river breath. Arla watches you with a mix of alarm and relief, counting the seconds you steal from the world and returning them like a book you fear to keep overdue. The mountain exhales not as surrender but as consent, and you taste iron and river on your tongue, the two treaties you have always tried to keep held in it.
choices.outcome: The note does not vanish; it learns manners, and the shaft’s voice becomes something that guides instead of goads, though for a day or two everyone speaks softer than they must as if not to wake a child. Sera pays in scrip and respect, but she pinches your bell-hand in both of hers and hisses that if you ever smother a work-song again without warning her first, she will throw you out of her tunnels by your own belt. Arla writes a private report to the Lantern Court praising your restraint and warning of the tool you carry, and for a while the Tidewardens are seen more often at the Pass as if silence itself were contraband. Dorn’s tests reveal the chip vibrates in sympathy with the Diadem’s secret hum, and he asks—too casually—if you plan to use the hush on the city’s bones if the bells ever demand it. The storage roads open to you, the Guild of Azurites marks you as a friend who keeps work alive, and word drifts through the Bazaar that you can buy quiet from you but should not try to steal it.

choices.title: Answer the empire’s score and turn it upon itself
choices.text: You read the copper like a scholar who grew up counting river bells, and you decide the safest path is paradox: meet the war-song with its own refrain, but bend it through rests until it forgets how to march. You tap the plates in a sequence that recalls the empire’s cadence without obeying it, weaving pauses where once there were commands, until the shaft’s note starts tripping over its own orders. Arla sets her palm on the wall and hums a counterline too low to carry, and you and she become a hinge that swings the sound to a safer angle. The wedge becomes less a stopper and more a consonant, a letter placed into a word that was always missing it; the mountain’s grammar softens into sense. Sweat beads under your gloves and copper dust coats your teeth, but when you step back the air seems to expand, like a crowd remembering to breathe after a verdict goes the right way.
choices.outcome: The amplification collapses without a collapse of rock, and the new measure settles into the old like a well-fitted joint, strong without show. Miners test the timing with boots and picks, and soon their work-song returns, altered but proud, a hymn that honors both the old empire and the living wage. Sera claps you on the shoulder and admits, through her veil, that she feared you would either grandstand or run, and instead you listened and made the mountain listen back; her payment and promise follow as agreed. Dorn’s analysis finds that the chip you deliver sings a harmony line to the Diadem’s hum rather than its melody, a clue that whatever plucks the city’s strings has more than one hand. Your name travels the storage roads ahead of you, the Guild’s standing rises by one in your favor, and a rumor takes root that you can hear contracts in stone and choose which clauses to honor.

rewards.description: Resonant Stone Tuning Fork (tool that reveals safe frequencies)
Bundle of iron scrip redeemable in Veylcrest foundries
Access to Ironsung Pass storage roads (faster travel)
